_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
re is an oxidation reduction probe on tank F-31 to prevent it from overchlorinating.  Tank F-31, F-32, and F-34 are ferrous chloride tanks that can absorb chlorine from a fully open valve.  Each tank is equiped with a relief set at 20" water column vacuum and 40" water column pressure to prevent tank rupture.  The system operates at a slight vacuum so that air will pull into the system if there is a leak.The system has over pressure alarms.

Chlorine gas is piped from the railcars to the reaction vessels, where it reacts with ferrous chloride to form ferric chloride.


4.  General accidental release prevention program

This facility has a strong commitment to the safe handling of chlorine and to minimizing the probability of an accidental release.  This is achieved through a combination of personnel training, process safety equipment, and operating procedures.

5.  Five-year accident history

There has been no accidental releases of Chlorine in the past 5 years.

6.  Emergency Response Program

The facility has a comprehensive emergency response program.  The Emergency Response Plan contains specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of chlorine, procedures to inform the public and health care information.  All employees working with chlorine are given 40 hour Hazwoper training with annual 8 hour refreshers.   This plan has been coordinated with the St. Louis LEPC.  The telephone number fo the LEPC is (314)  289-1900.

7.  Planned changes to improve safety

The system was changed in 2005 to continuous to be safer.  No new plans needed at this time.
